newsitem.title: UK: FOCUS - German crude sale plan knocks oil price.
newsitem.headline: FOCUS - German crude sale plan knocks oil price.

text.p: Oil prices fell further on Thursday, hit by Germany's decision to sell off 400 million marks ($230 million) worth of strategic crude reserves this year to plug a growing budget deficit.

The sale would release at least 75,000 barrels per day -- equal to a medium-sized North Sea oilfield -- onto a healthily supplied market already braced for the second wave of Iraqi exports under a United Nations oil-for-food plan.
"The timing is immaculate but if the German government believes (oil) prices are going lower then it makes sense for them," said Geoff Pyne, oil analyst at Swiss bank UBS.
The news knocked North Sea Brent crude under $18 a barrel on the London futures market. The international benchmark deepened Wednesday's losses to close 26 cents down at $17.96.
The oil, kept in salt caverns near the northern port of Wilhemshaven, was stored shortly after the oil price shock of 1974.
Bonn government sources also said that further sales would follow next year
Economics minister Guenter Rexrodt said last month that Bonn was considering selling 7.3 million tonnes of oil.
The government said at the time that this was one of the measures under consideration to cut the budget deficits as Germany struggles to qualify for European monetary union.
Today's decision was deplored by the International Energy Agency (IEA), set up by the West after the '70s oil price shock to monitor stocks in the key global economies.
Up to 750,000 barrels per day of Iraqi crude could also soon be adding to world supply if the U.N. approves Baghdad's plan for distributing aid, submitted in draft form on Wednesday.
"The key news that the market is waiting for is whether or not the Iraqi plan is acceptable to the U.N.," said brokers GNI in a report earlier today.
Iraqi officials will meet with Staffan de Mistura, the U.N. representative in Baghdad, on Saturday for further talks.

De Mistura, told Reuters on Wednesday the distribution plan required further work before it could be submitted to U.N. Secretary-General Kofi Annan for approval, but he gave no indication how long this would take.
Under the terms of the U.N. plan implemented last December, Baghdad is allowed to sell $2 billion of oil over 180 days to raise money for humanitarian imports.
The deal was renewed on June 8 but Iraq has suspended exports pending the completion of improved arrangements for getting food and medicines to central and southern parts of the country.
Analysts say Iraq's return could push Brent crude back towards the 13-month low of $17.32 a barrel posted in mid-June, as the extra barrels flow into heavily swollen stocks.
Crude oil prices in dollars per barrel:
July 10 July 9
(close) (close)
Dated Brent $18.06 $18.32
IPE August Brent $17.96 $18.22
NYMEX August light crude $19.21 $19.42
--London newsroom +44 171 542 7930
